content.body: Hey, I was looking through some of the notes from the last plenary, and I noticed that for "Don't call well-known Symbol methods for RegExp on primitive values", it was pointed out that core-js implements the proposed PR rather than the spec
and that doesn't seem to be true: https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/master/packages/core-js/modules/es.string.match.js#L20
I assume that claim was based on https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/3009#issuecomment-1451639187
I somehow missed that comment when looking through that issue ðŸ˜…
but yeah, overriding `String.prototype[Symbol.match]` does make core-js's `String.prototype.match` polyfill throw
content.formatted_body: but yeah, overriding String.prototype[Symbol.match] does make core-js's String.prototype.match polyfill throw

content.body: * but yeah, overriding `String.prototype[Symbol.match]` to throw does make core-js's `String.prototype.match` polyfill throw
content.formatted_body: * but yeah, overriding String.prototype[Symbol.match] to throw does make core-js's String.prototype.match polyfill throw

m.new_content.body: but yeah, overriding `String.prototype[Symbol.match]` to throw does make core-js's `String.prototype.match` polyfill throw
m.new_content.formatted_body: but yeah, overriding String.prototype[Symbol.match] to throw does make core-js's String.prototype.match polyfill throw
